definitions.definition: to make something longer, wider or looser, for example by pulling it; to become longer, etc. in this way

examples.text: Is there any way of stretching shoes?
Stop stretching your sleeves like that!
This sweater has stretched.

definitions.definition: to become bigger or longer when you pull it and return to its original shape when you stop

examples.text: The jeans stretch to provide a perfect fit.

definitions.definition: to pull something so that it is smooth and tight

examples.text: Stretch the fabric tightly over the frame.
Striped awnings had been stretched across the courtyard.
Make sure that the rope is stretched tight.

definitions.definition: to put your arms or legs out straight and contract your muscles

examples.text: He stretched and yawned lazily.
Andrea turned out the light and stretched full-length on the bed.
The exercises are designed to stretch and tone your leg muscles.
It was impossible to bend or stretch my legs.

definitions.definition: to put out an arm or a leg in order to reach something

examples.text: She stretched across the table for the butter.
She stretched up to reach the top shelf.
I stretched out a hand and picked up the book.

definitions.definition: to spread over an area of land

examples.text: Fields and hills stretched out as far as we could see.
The traffic jam seemed to **stretch for miles**.
A line of cars stretched into the distance.
The flat landscape stretched to the horizon.
Beyond the mountains stretches a vast desert.
The beach seemed to stretch endlessly.
The road stretched ahead.
The wood does not stretch very far.
an area which stretches from London to the north

definitions.definition: to continue over a period of time

examples.text: The town's history stretches back to before 1500.
to stretch back years/decades/generations/centuries
The training stretches over a period of 16 months.
Endless summer days stretched out before us.
The talks look set to stretch into a second week.
The future stretched out endlessly in front of me.

definitions.definition: to be enough to buy or pay for something

examples.text: I need a new car, but my savings won't stretch to it.
There are lots of things I’d like to buy, but our budget just won’t stretch that far.

definitions.definition: to make use of a lot of your money, supplies, time, etc.

examples.text: The pandemic has **stretched** healthcare resources **to the limit**.
We can't take on any more work—we're fully stretched as it is.
The budget is already **stretched to breaking point**.
The influx of tourists in the summer stretches the capacity of local transport to its limit.
Our forces are too thinly stretched to control the chaos.
The increase in demand has severely stretched our resources.
Don't stretch yourself too thin financially.
This department is stretched to its limit.

definitions.definition: to increase your lead over somebody in a game or competition

examples.text: A minute later, Kelly stretched their lead to eight points.

definitions.definition: to make use of all somebody’s skill, intelligence, etc.

examples.text: I need a job that will stretch me.
She was never really stretched at school.
The book really stretches your imagination.

definitions.definition: to use something in a way that would not normally be considered fair, acceptable, etc.

examples.text: He admitted that he had maybe **stretched the truth** a little *(= not been completely honest)*.
The play's plot **stretches** credulity **to the limit**.

definitions.definition: to change the rules to suit a particular person or situation

examples.text: Couldn't they just bend the rules and let us in without a ticket?

definitions.definition: to go for a short walk after sitting for some time

examples.text: It was good to get out of the car and stretch our legs.

definitions.definition: to allow or do something that is not usually acceptable, especially because of a particular situation

examples.text: I was hoping they would stretch a point and let me stay on for a while.

wordOrigin: Old English streccan, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch strekken and German strecken. The noun dates from the late 16th cent.
